item.description:
Report E-2024020148

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-12T18:12:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-02
  • City: SPRINGFIELD
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 2, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1263 was crushed in transit and released approximately two (2) ounces of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. ES personnel deployed granular absorbents to the paint-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents and the damaged pail were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum.

item.title: Report E-2024020147
item.description:
Report E-2024020147

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-12T18:12:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-02
  • City: SHARPSVILLE
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 2, 2024, three (3) 5-gallon pails of UN1263 were punctured by a metal rod in transit and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel found three (3) damaged 5-gallon pails, removed them from the load, and placed them into one (1) 55-gallon drum that was fitted with proper labels for return to the terminal. Crews utilized granular absorbents to collect the released product from the trailer and freight, and all spent absorbents and any cleanup debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 5-gallon bucket that was taken back to the terminal by FCE personnel.

item.title: Report E-2024020146
item.description:
Report E-2024020146

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-12T18:12:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-01
  • City: COLUMBIANA
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On February 1, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN3082 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately thirty (30) gallons of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the UN3082-impacted dock floor and swept them in with hand tools. Crews observed that they would not be able to lift the tote for a gravity feed and instead did a bucket transfer of all the remaining contents into an additional 330-gallon tote. All spent absorbents, clean up debris, and cut up 330-gallon tote were collected and containerized into five (5) 55-gallon drums for terminal disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024020078
item.description:
Report E-2024020078

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-12T18:12:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-02-05
  • City: FORT DODGE
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XFO experienced a UN3082 Caromax 28 release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-gallons of product released to a 3’ x 2’ area of the wooden trailer floor and a 1’ x 1’ area of the concrete dock floor due to a crack in the top corner of the tote. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all impacted absorbents into (2) 55- gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Carrier/Reporter: BNSF RAILWAY COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 1/22/24, BNSF Portland IMF notified LARS of destination unit JBHU 332772 (billed HAZ, UN 1263, Flammable Aluminum Paint) which was observed to be leaking a liquid during the de ramping process. Upon inspection US Ecology observed a standard shipment of multiple 55g drums, the securement straps failed during transit, allowing the drums to shift. 1, 55 gallon drum had a pinpoint hole in the bottom of it, allowing approximately 5 gallons to leak from the drum.

  • Description: On January 30, 2024, two (2) 55-gallon drums of UN1760 were leaking from the bungs and released approximately less than one (<1) cup of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Hazmat Services (EHS) to remediate the impacted site. Crews wiped down the released product with cleaners and absorbent pads. EHS personnel placed the damaged 55-gallon drum into one (1) 95-gallon poly overpack, and the one (1) undamaged 55-gallon drum and one (1) 95-gallon overpack were placed onto a pallet and gift wrapped for return to the terminal. Crews took one (1) poly liner of the absorbent pads and cleanup debris back to their shop.

item.title: Report X-2024020462

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-23
  • City: LINCOLNTON
  • State: NC

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: A package handler noticed a smell coming from the box and had it sent to QA area. It was not actually leaking outside of the box, but I also smelled it so I placed it in a plastic tote and moved it away from the work area until I could deal with it. DescribePack: Package was a sturdy cardboard box with a white, plastic 5.0 gal pail inside the box. The shipping box was not damaged at all but the pail was busted on the bottom and cracked all the way up the side of the pail. From the damage to the pail it appears the box was dropped or slammed down, causing the bottom to burst. The lid was still intact, still sealed , not damaged. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The spilled contents stayed confined to the box initially. The contents of the package was transferred to a Hazmat drum as soon as possible. The plastic pail and the contents had to be transferred to the Hazmat drum because there was no hazmat drum big enough for the entire box to fit into. I folded the box down ,placed in a hazmat bag and another hazmat drum.

  • City: FAIRFIELD
  • State: NJ

  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On the morning of January 30, 2024, a Veolia employee was at the customer site loading a drum of sulfuric acid into their trailer when the incident occurred. The Veolia employee was maneuvering the drum to the edge of the dock, however there was no dock leveler or dock plate. The employee proceeded to get the drum cart and pick up and move the drum the rest of the way when one of the forks from the drum cart pierced the drum. The customer came to assist and pumped the damaged drum into a new drum. The damaged drum was then put into an overpack. The Veolia supervisor and EHS manager responded to assist by contacting the remediation/ spill response team to respond with a neutralizer so the truck can be cleaned up and the job can resume.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While at truckstop, a leak was detected coming from trailer. Posen Fire Department was dispatched to assess. Area was isolated and Hazchem Environmental Corp was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, Hazchem applied absorbent material to the affected asphalt and inpsected the trailer. One 55-gallon drum was discovered at nose of trailer, which had been punctured by a sharp object in transit. Hazchem proceeded to offload the trailer, overpacked the damaged drum, and cleaned the trailer floor. All spent absorbents were recovered from trailer floor and affected asphalt, which were placed into two 55-gallon drums. Product was contained to an impervious surface and did not threaten to impact surface soils or state waters. Two 55-gallon drums of spent absorbents and cleanup debris, and one overpack drum, were generated during cleanup, which were transported off site pending disposal. There were no injuries or exposures reported. ,

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Patriot Environmental Services was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 1ft- by-1ft area of the trailer floor and a 1ft-by-1ft area of the concrete parking lot and estimated that two (2) pounds of material was released due to load shift that damaged one (1) plastic bag. Patriot Environmental Services personnel deployed absorbents to the impacted areas and recovered the spent material. The impacted areas were then treated with a neutralizer. The spent material that was recovered was containerized into one (1) 15-gallon poly drum and the damaged 50-pound plastic bag along with the remaining product was placed into one (1) additional 15-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite until the waste profile has been completed and approved for transport for disposal.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-12T18:12:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-24
  • City: LYNNFIELD
  • State: MA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: THE PACKAGE WAS UNLOADED, PALED AND SENT TO THE SORT AISLE AND SORTED INTO THE BOXLINE. THE PRELOADER NOTICED IT WAS LEAKING. HE LEFT THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HIS SUPERVISOR. THE SUPERVISOR THEN CALLED FOR A DESIGNATED RESPONDER. THE RESPONDER, FOLLWING THE DECISION TREE AND APPROPRIATE RESPONCE SHEET, PLACED THE PACKAGE INTO A LINED SPILL TUB. THE EQUIPMENT WAS CLEANED FOLLOWING THE EQUIPMENT DECONTAMINATION CHECKLIST. THE PACKAGE WAS THEN TRANSPORTED TO THE DMP AREA FOR FUTHER PROCESSING. IT WAS THEN, THE PACKAGE WAS DISCOVERED TO BE UNDECLARED.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 29, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of isopropanol was damaged in transit due to a load strap failure and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews overpacked the damaged 55-gallon drum into one (1) 85-gallon salvage drum. HCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the released product and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents, any cleanup debris, and PPE were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum that was staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A DANGEROUS GOODS DECLARED PACKAGE THAT HAD PREVIOUSLY PASSED AN ACCEPTANCE AUDIT AT THE ORIGIN FACLITY IN THE USA WAS DISCOVERED LEAKING IN THE UNITED KINGDOM. THE PACKAGE IS PROPERLY PREPARED AS UN3363, DANGEROUS GOODS IN APPARATUS WITH AN APPROPRIATE IATA SHIPPERS DECLARATION, CLASS 9 DIAMOND LABEL AND ORIENTATION ARROWS. INNER CONTENT INSPECTION REVEALS AN AIRCRAFT PART ENCLOSED AND ZIPTIED WITHIN A PLASTIC BAG. THERE IS A SMALL PUNCTURE IN THE BAG CONSISTENT WITH THE SHAPE OF THE PART INSIDE THE BAG. THE OUTER FIBERBOARD BOX HAS ALSO BEEN PUNCTURED SLIGHTLY CONSISTENT TO THE SAME COMPROMISED LOCATION. PAPERWORK INSIDE THE PACKAGE INDICATES THE PRODUCT AS "8120-2 FUEL OIL COOLER OIL LEAK FTN 5M3095". THE INVOICE AND THERMAL LABEL DESCRIPTION OF THE COMMODITY IS A COOLER. PRIOR TO THE LEAKING DISCOVERY THE PACKAGE WAS FLOWN ON UPS AIRCRAFT FROM ATL TO SDF AND SDF TO PHL TO EMA.

  • Description: On January 31, 2024, one (1) 1-gallon pail of UN1263 was forked and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. ES personnel utilized hand tools and absorbents to remediate the UN1263-impacted trailer. ES personnel solidified the damaged pail of product and all impacted debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum which was taken into possession by ES personnel for disposal.

item.title: Report I-2024100053
item.description:
Report I-2024100053

Identified by scraper @ 2024-02-12T18:12:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-12
  • City: Charlotte
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERICAN AIRLINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Passenger Drake Cox informed us of his laptop overheating inside of his backpack. When we got out the fire containment bag, he decided to bring the whole backpack to us. We put on the heat resistant gloves and a second Flight Attendant helped me with pouring a Iiter of water on the inside of the fire containment bag. I removed the laptop from the backpack and placed it in the fire containment bag with the battery facing down. The second Flight Attendant cleared out a galley cart and we placed the fire containment bag in the furthest aircraft right galley cart in the AFT of the aircraft. We continued to monitor the laptop throughout the rest of the flight, but no further action was needed. Once we arrived and all the passengers deplaned, the entire cart was brought to the forward galley as per the Supervisofs request and that's when the Supervisor told us Flight Attendants we were ok to leave and the rest would be taken care of. The laptop was an Apple MacBook Pro.
